reviewText: Movie - 4.5Every now and then, I'm sure people find a movie that manages to fly under the radar and gets a lot less credit than it deserves, or in layman's terms, "a diamond in the rough." I discovered such a gem when deciding to give An Education a rent based solely on the one time I saw a trailer for it on another Sony BD. Aside from the presence of the always-proficient class act, Alfred Molina, nothing else at the time really struck me as "wow, I have to see this." I knew the movie would be a British-produced, coming of age, slice-of-life, semi-period piece about a girl, but that's it. Thankfully, the film itself easily defied a lot of the preconceived notions I had going in. An Education is a quaint, yet brilliantly written and directed story not just about a girl becoming a woman, but about the naivety, discovery, and eventual hardship I think all people are likely to feel and experience at some point in their lives. The script has a lot of charm and subtlety to it, which is wonderfully delivered and acted by (newcomers, to me) Carey Mulligan, Peter Sarsgaard, and for what few moments she has, Olivia Williams. The entire production actually reminds me of a lower-budgeted work that somehow just happened to be a really good thing in the end. It's neither flashy, nor does it feel like an exuberant amount of money went into any particular shot. But for some reason, it just works and feels like grade-A film-making. I know Mulligan was nominated for Best Actress, and while I've yet to see Sandra Bullock in The Blind Side, I would definitely vouch for Ms. Mulligan's fine performance, here. For those curious to check this movie out, I would say go in with the expectations of a low-key romantic drama. But at the same time, put yourself in Mulligan's shoes at that age and ask yourself what you think you'd do if you were her. It may sound a bit far-fetched, maybe even juvenile if you're not in to this genre, but I certainly feel a little more educated after watching it.Video - 4.0As I mentioned about the non-flashy presentation of the film itself, An Education looks pretty good given the period it was set in, the conservative nature of that time, and the fact that this isn''t some high-budget Hollywood blockbuster. Colors for a majority of the film range somewhere between drab and "one shiny moment" where Mulligan wears a particularly extravagant dress. Vibrancy isn't a strong point of the art direction, but I actually think it compliments the film's thematic progression very well. Skin tones are accurate, if not a tad pale, but brighten and fill up a bit when the main characters get into the night clubs and visit Paris. Contrast and black levels are adequate throughout revealing a good amount of object detail and facial features as well, with a little noise here and there during the more darkly-lit scenes, but overall never feels distracting. It's a video transfer that accurately showcases the film's artistic attributes and is another great job by Sony.Audio - 4.5Much more pleasing in presentation is the DTS-HD 5.1 track. Dialogue is clear and unfaltering through the center channel, with a decent amount of sound effects for cars, doors, and footsteps kept mainly on the front sides. High and low ends are handled as best as they can be for the limited sound design, with separation being good enough and directionality sparse. I thought it was going to be a front-heavy track initially, but music immersion is where the audio really shines. Throughout the film, we're treated to various instances of period jazz, big band, and swing music that have a tremendous amount of buoyancy outputting from all the speakers. And the fact that it even emanates some subtle LFEs only makes it more fun to listen to. The score by Paul Englishby has a good pace to it and never feels too melodramatic or overdone in any way. All in all, the music department did a great job making up for what the sound effects department lacked in presence.Extras - 2.0Aside from the somewhat jovial commentary with director Scherfig and actors Mulligan and Sarsgaard, there's not much else in terms of special features. The commentary itself dibbles and dabbles at the technical processes of the filming, the acting, and alterations made between filming and the final product, but never really gets too focused. It makes for a good listen, but is probably not something I'd say has a lot of replay value. In addition, there are also a couple of paltry vignettes featuring the making-of and red carpet arrival, though they do very little for me that isn't either covered in the commentary or that I can deduce on my own. However, given the low-key marketing the film itself received, the studio probably felt it would be in the company's best interest to keep the extras at a minimum, which is too bad. There also deleted scenes and Sony trailers.Overall - 4.0This movie really caught me by surprise. I only saw the trailer once and had very little expectations going in. Thankfully, it surprised the heck out of me with how well-written and directed it was. My biggest surprise, however, was the discovery of Carey Mulligan. She has a very subtle appearance, but a very strong screen presence. I'm hoping this film will open a lot of doors for her in the future. Presented by Sony with excellent A/V specs, though a disappointing set of extras, An Education comes highly recommended for movie-goers wanting an engaging character drama.

reviewText: **Warning--This review may contain spoilers**--'An Education' is a film rife with one implausible character after another. For starters, when we're introduced to the protagonist, high school student Jenny, she seems way too sophisticated for a 16 year old. The main problem is that Carey Mulligan, who plays Jenny, is 24 years old in real life. Why didn't they cast a teenager?Then there's the problem of the girl's father, Jack. At first he appears extremely petulant, a caricature of the pushy parent who wants their child to succeed at any cost. With his insistence that Jenny study night and day in order to get into Oxford, we're first led to believe that he's the film's antagonist. But soon when con-artist David appears on the scene, Jack is suddenly reduced to unprincipled buffoon. I say buffoon because he's so easily taken in by David's scheme--that David is actually an Oxford alumni and knows famous Oxford professor/author C.S Lewis. If this was a real character, wouldn't have Jack made a few simple inquiries to determine whether David was telling the truth or not?In very simplistic fashion, the implication here is Jenny's sudden embrace of a life of crime is due to Jack's lack of principles. David basically buys Jack's acquiescence in allowing Jenny's trips away from home and ultimately accepting the idea of Jenny and David tying the knot. Somehow all this so easily rubs off on impressionable Jenny. The gutless father figure is nothing new--just think of Jim Backus strutting around in an apron in 'Rebel without a cause'.Perhaps the moment I found to be the most incredulous was Jenny's sudden transformation from earnest student to unsavory bad girl. Even with the father acting the way he did, would she have so suddenly embraced David once she discovers that he's a con artist? I would think that a normal teenager would have been very alarmed that she was now in the company of a bunch of criminals and fear would have entered into the equation. But what was Jenny's reaction? A mild protest and then David sweeps her off her feet.David was disappointing in that he was such a tame sociopath. What are his crimes? Well, he steals an antique map from a house that's up for sale and arranges for minorities to move into apartment buildings, scaring elderly tenants, and then buying the apartments from them when they decide to leave, at cut-rate prices. Oh yes, he also cheats on his wife. Equally disappointing is the couple he hangs out with--except for one scene where there is a confrontation with Jenny, they really have little to do.Every melodrama needs a villain and that is of course the headmistress of the school Jenny attends. After she finds out David is Jewish, she blurts out that the Jews "killed our Lord". Not only is she depicted as a vile anti-Semite but she cruelly rejects Jenny's request to be reinstated. Only Jenny's kindly teacher is willing to give her encouragement.There is nothing subtle about 'An Education'. It's an old-fashioned morality play where the good guys (educated professionals) triumph over shiftless petty criminals who hang out at such unsavory venues as dog tracks and seedy nightclubs. Everything is tied up in a nice ribbon at the end when both Jenny and her father repent and Jenny is miraculously accepted into Oxford.'An Education' is a tawdry little tale that has already garnered a good share of undeserved accolades. It does boast a nice recreation of early 60s London along with a brooding score but in terms of psychological insight and depth of character, it totally lacks any kind of aesthetic credibility.

At first she is reluctant, after all David is roughly twice her age, but eventually she relents, worn down by his considerable charm.  Afterwards, David, with the consent of Jenny's parents starts to show her that there are other things in life other than school and study.David introduces Jenny to his running mates Danny (Dominic Cooper ~ The Duchess, Mamma Mia, The History Boys) and Helen (Roseamund Pike ~ Pride & Prejudice, Die Another Day, Fracture) and together the four start to live the high life and educating Jenny.My Thoughts"An Education" is a bore! And there were considerable problems with the script.  First, what self-respecting parents would let their 16-year old daughter spend afternoons and evenings, let alone weekends away with a grown man twice her age?  Seriously?  In fact everyone in this deflated little tale is made to look like a clown in order to make Jenny, the protagonist appear worldlier than her 16 years would otherwise suggest.And where was the romance in this little farce? reviewText: From a purely cinematographic viewpoint this movie probably deserves only 4 stars: it's very good, but not spectacular as far as the camera work and actors performances are concerned. Still I gave it 5 stars because of the underlying story, based on Lynn Barber memoir of her life in the 1950s.The story is about young girl (Jenny) in her last years of school, preparing for college. She's very smart, self-confident, one of the best students in her class, she plays classical music in the school orchestra, studies Latin and French, and is expected to apply for Oxford.At the same time she lives with her middle-class parents in a quiet but boring London suburb, while real life is going elswehre: some people spend their time going to nice concert halls, traveling to Paris, dining & dancing in beautiful restaurants...All this becomes a possibility for her when she meets David, a man who seems to be able to make all her dreams come true. And - on top of that - he's young enough, around 30, and charming enough, to make him a viable candidate for falling in love with him.The only problem is - the more Jenny knows David, the more he proves to be a crook, making his living off anything from shady real estated dealings up to outright theft.Every time Jenny finds out next detail about dark side of David's life, she's initially appalled, but then she lets herself to be persuaded that there's nothing inherently wrong in whatever David does - as long as he loves her (and, incidentially, spends his money on taking her on nice trips, to expensive restaurants etc).Looks like Jenny would accept anything David does, and finally she agrees to become his wife when he proposes the marriage. But it turns out there's a limit to Jenny's acceptance. At the eve of her wedding she finds out that David is already married. Next day she goes to see his wife and a child - and this becomes too much for her.At the very beginning David tells Jenny that he's a Jew, and there are many scenes in the movie that show various attitudes to the Jews in the British society in the middle of the last century. Some people would certainly find this movie anti-Semitic (see, for instance, "British Film Gives `An Education' in Anti-Semitism" by Irina Bragin).In fact, this film can be rather considered anti-British or misogynistic, if one looks at Jenny's moral flexibility in accepting favors from David. It becomes "too much" for her only when it comes out that she's one of his victims herself. Also one cannot avoid seeing the way her parents shown in this movie as somewhat satirical, if not outright sarcastic.In general, this is one of the films which become more interesting as time passes, when you have a chance to think of what you saw, to discuss it with friends, because everything in this film has some meaning, not a single scene is wasted, everything is to the point. Takes some time to understand it, and it definitely deserves more than one viewing.

She works hard and knows that going to university will likely lead to a teaching career; her life will be much like the one lead by her supportive but bland teacher, Miss Stubbs (Olivia Williams). She ends up dating David and being sucked into his world, which involves exciting trips to Paris, suppers at chic jazz clubs, and parties with David's rich friends.  Is Peter "educating" Jenny about how exciting life can be, or will Jenny's education involve something else, perhaps something less pleasant?"An Education" is a well-acted period piece.  Carey Mulligan has received numerous nominations (including for an Academy Award) for her turn as Jenny.  The 24-year-old actress does a beautiful job with her difficult role, which begins as a wide-eyed 16-year-old and ends somewhere else entirely.  Peter Sarsgaard is also quite good; he keeps his character's intentions murky enough so that we never know whether to trust him.  The look of the film is quite nice, and I particularly enjoyed how it captured the early 1960s jazz scene.  I'm sure that many viewers will wish that they could be in Jenny's place.  Surprisingly, the Danish director (Lone Scherfig) is an adherent to Dogme95, although I don't see any trace of that aesthetic in this film, her first in English.  The script, by write Nick Hornby is based on an autobiographical article by journalist Lynn Barber; I generally like Hornby's work, and at times "An Education" is quite funny.  Hornsby received his first Oscar nomination for the script (the film based on his novel "About a Boy" was also nominated for Best Adapted Screenplay, but Hornby did not write that script).Despite the film's strengths, it ended up falling a bit flat for me.  First, I never bought into the reaction of her Jenny's parents to David - they're more easily seduced than is Jenny!  Second, it was difficult to understand how Jenny herself could so quickly turn against the academics that were previously the center of her world.  The transformation from dreamy schoolgirl to partying clubgoer was a bit too abrupt and the audience could have benefitted from hearing Jenny's thoughts on the matter.  Finally, the main story (young woman used by an older man) is a familiar one, and I don't think "An Education" added much new to the genre. What a treat - great story telling infused with the credibility of fine acting and accesorized with vistas from the English countryside and Paris.The lead actress is a better version of Katie Holmes at her age, I think she is headed for great things. She has truly mastered the ability to both play an intellectually superior and tenderly cocky adolescent - most often with facial expression- but equally be a fragile child in the presence of Peter's character. Ah-ha and I just looked her up after writing that, she was nominated for a Golden Globe for this role. :)This is an enjoyable film for anyone with an interest in the topic.

reviewText: Set in 60s London, "An Education" centers on 16-year-old Jenny (Carey Mulligan delivering a finely-nuanced performance) who is preparing for her 'A' Levels for entrance into Oxford University. Jenny plays the cello, has a keen eye for art, and wants to read English at Oxford. Her father Jack (credibly portrayed by Alfred Molina) wishes to see his only child in a prestigious university as a means of elevating their status as a family. A rainy day changes everything as Jenny's path crosses that of a smooth-talking older man, David (Peter Skarsgaard who delivers a compelling performance despite a rather weak English accent). David entices Jenny to take a ride in his coveted Bristol and Jenny finds herself slowly but surely falling for Peter and his sophisticated ways. The pair dine out in fancy restaurants, listen to jazz music in cool clubs, and live the high life together with Peter's friends, Danny (Dominic Cooper, who has also appeared in movies such asMamma Mia! The Movie (Widescreen)and as James Willoughby inSense & Sensibility (with Miss Austen Regrets) (BBC TV 2008)and Danny's girlfriend Helen (Rosamund Pike, who has also appeared in a BBC period drama,Wives and Daughters. Suddenly, the previously sheltered Jenny finds herself being swept off her feet and introduced to a sophisticated, fun new world she had only dreamed of in the past.Inevitably, the once studious and hardworking Jenny begins to falter as her studies take a backseat to nights out, weekends off in the country, and even a trip to Paris. Her parents fall for David's charm and the social climbing Jack goes as far as to determine that Jenny might as well give up Oxford if she manages to get David to marry her. No one really has a clue as to how David manages to finance his high-flying lifestyle, though Jenny does find out sometime in the movie and begins to see a darker side to David and his life. There are more revelations to come before the movie ends, and the question is: Will Jenny be able to realize her potential? Will her informal "education" procured during her time with David be sufficient for her or is there still a place for formal schooling in her life?I thought the film was beautifully made - the scenic setting, the 60s lifestyle and the myriad themes explored all blend together convincingly to create a truly poignant coming-of-age tale. Carey Mulligan (who first impressed me in a secondary role inMasterpiece Theatre: Northanger Abbeydelivers both a delightful and heartbreaking performance as the confident yet ultimately vulnerable young child-woman. The chemistry between Mulligan's Jenny and Skarsgaard's David is credible and powerful - one can see that there's a certain neediness in David that is assuaged by being with the young Jenny, and Jenny in turn is intoxicated by the power she wields over David. The rather sensitive issue of sex between a 17-year-old and a much older man is subtly addressed and there are no exploitative or gratuitous scenes to offend anyone's sensibilities (though it probably merits mentioning that the age of consent in Britain is 16).Final verdict - a fine coming-of-age tale set in a time when the sexual revolution and feminism were about to take serious flight.
